key_title: Key to the species of Allocasuarina

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Casuarinaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Casuarinaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1996). Casuarinaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Bark smooth, fissured or furrowed; cone valves usually with a single abaxial protuberance (occasionally with 2 lateral bodies)
Bark smooth or finely striate; cone valves subdivided into 3–5 parts (giving cones a smoothish outline with a chequered surface); East Gippsland only
Trees; branchlets minutely roughened; teeth 9–14 per whorl
Shrubs or trees; branchlets smooth or rib minutely serrate in profile; teeth 4–11 per whorl
Branchlets ascending; teeth erect, tightly appressed; cones broader than long, with valves in 2 or 3 wheel-like rows
Branchlets drooping; teeth spreading; cones longer than broad, with valves in several rows
Branchlet ribs with median groove
Branchlet ribs without median groove
Teeth not overlapping
Teeth overlapping; Big and Little Deserts only
Teeth overlapping at least at base when young
Teeth not overlapping (mostly not withered)
Branchlet ribs flat or slightly rounded
Branchlet ribs angular or strongly rounded, with keel or convexity continued onto teeth
Teeth 7–10, more than 0.5 mm long, spreading to recurved, strongly withered; branchlet furrows pubescent or glabrous
Teeth 5–7, 0.5 mm long or less, erect to spreading, not withered or slightly so at apex; branchlet furrows glabrous
Branchlet internodes without a waxy bloom; teeth 5–11, recurved to erect, often withered; cones sessile or on peduncle to 5 mm long
Branchlet internodes with a waxy bloom at least when dry; teeth 6 or 7, erect, not withered; cones on peduncle 2–12 mm long; Grampians only
Teeth 7–11, recurved to spreading
Teeth 5–7, erect and appressed to occasionally spreading
Teeth strongly withered; branchlet ribs only slightly rounded, furrows pubescent or glabrous, but always pubescent if in the Grampians; west of Melbourne
Teeth mostly somewhat withered; branchlet ribs rounded, furrows glabrous; Grampians and allied mountains, and east of Melbourne
Branchlet furrows glabrous or if pubescent, ribs with minutely serrate central keel
Branchlet furrows obviously pubescent, ribs without minutely serrate central keel; mostly tree 5–15 m, but sometimes smaller shrub
Branchlet ribs angular, rounded or flat
Branchlet ribs sharply angular with minutely serrate keel, often whitish; teeth erect and appressed; west of Melbourne only
Branchlet ribs rounded or angular; teeth erect but not appressed; winged seed 5–8 mm long (rarely to 3.5 mm long in A. diminuta)
Branchlet ribs flat to rounded; teeth usually appressed; winged seed c. 4 mm long
Branchlets with strong waxy bloom; Grampians
Branchlets with waxy bloom faint or absent; east and north-east of Melbourne only
Shrubs to 3 m tall; cones robust, mostly more than 20 mm long and 10 mm diam.; seeds 5–8 mm long
Trees or tall shrubs 3–5 m tall; cones small, mostly less than 20 mm long and 10 mm diam.; seeds 3.5–5 mm long
